quest_title: The apparent weight of a body inside a lift accelerating downwards with 2 m/s\({}^{2}\) is 200 N. The apparent weight of same body if lift accelerating upwards with 2 m/s\({}^{2}\) is
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(a\) = 2 m/s\(^{2}\)\(\quad\)\(\quad\)

\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(mg\) - \(R\) = \(ma\)

\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(R\) = \(mg\) - \(ma\)

\(\quad\)Or,\(\quad\)\(m\) = \( \cfrac{200}{10 - 2} \)= \( \cfrac{200}{8} \)kg\(\quad\)

\(\quad\)Again,

\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(R'\) - \(mg\) = \(ma\)

\(\quad\)Or,\(\quad\)\(R'\) = \(mg\) + \(ma\) = \(m \)(\(g\) + \(a\)) = \( \cfrac{200}{8} \)\(\times \) 12

\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\( \quad\)\(\quad\)\(\quad\) = 300 N

quest_title: A telescope has an objective lens of focal length 200 \(\textit{cm}\) and an eye piece with focal length 2 \(\textit{cm}\). If this telescope is used to see a 50 \(\textit{meter}\) tall building at a distance of 2 \(\textit{km}\), what is the height of the image of the building formed by the objective lens
explanation_txt:
Let \(I\) and \(O\) be the height of image and object respectively.

Magnification of objective lens \(M_{O}=\cfrac{I}{O} =\cfrac{v_{0} }{u_{0} } =\cfrac{f_{0} }{u_{0} } \) [When object is very far from the lens, image is formed at focus]

\(\Rightarrow \) \(\cfrac{I}{50} =\cfrac{200\times 10^{-2} }{2\times 10^{3} } \)

\(\Rightarrow \) \(\textit{I}= 5 \times 10{}^{-2}\) \(\textit{m} = 5 \, \textit{cm}\).

explanation_plain_text:
Let and be the height of image and object respectively.

Magnification of objective lens [When object is very far from the lens, image is formed at focus]

quest_title: The primary winding of a transformer has 100 turns and its secondary winding has 200 turns. The primary is connected to an AC of supply of 120 V and current flowing through it is 10 A. The voltage and current in the secondary are
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \cfrac{E_{S}}{E_{P}}=\cfrac{n_{S}}{n_{P}} & \Rightarrow E_{S}=E_{P} \times\left(\cfrac{n_{S}}{n_{P}}\right) \\ & \therefore E_{S}=120 \times\left(\cfrac{200}{100}\right)=240 \mathrm{V} \\ \cfrac{I_{S}}{I_{P}}=\cfrac{n_{P}}{n_{S}} & \Rightarrow I_{S}=I_{P}\left(\cfrac{n_{P}}{n_{S}}\right) \\ & \Rightarrow I_{S}=10 \times\left(\cfrac{100}{200}\right)=5 \mathrm{Amp} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: By inserting a capillary tube up to a depth l in water, the water rises to a height h. If the lower end of the capillary is closed inside water and the capillary is taken out and closed end opened, to what height the water will remain in the tube
explanation_txt: Liquid will not fall from the tube while opening the closed end due to surface tension. So, the height of liquid remaining on the tube is same as h.

quest_title: 4gm of NaOH (mol.wt = 40) were dissolved in water and the solution was made to 1000ml. The whole of this will neutralize completely.
explanation_txt:
No. of gram equivalents = \(\cfrac{4}{40}\) = 0.1

Checking the options for same value of gram equivalents,

for option c,

20 ml of 2.5M H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) = 20 ml of 5M H\(_2\)SO\(_4\)

No. of gram equivalent of H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) = 0.02 * 5 = 0.1

So, option c is correct.
question_plain_title: 4gm of NaOH (mol.wt = 40) were dissolved in water and the solution was made to 1000ml. The whole of this will neutralize completely.
explanation_plain_text:
No. of gram equivalents = = 0.1

Checking the options for same value of gram equivalents,

for option c,

20 ml of 2.5M HSO = 20 ml of 5M HSO

No. of gram equivalent of HSO = 0.02 * 5 = 0.1

So, option c is correct.

quest_title: If the function \(f(x)=x^{3} -6x^{2} +ax+b\) satisfies Rolle's theorem in the interval \([1,\, 3]\) and \(f'\left(\cfrac{2\sqrt{3} +1}{\sqrt{3} } \right)=0\), then
explanation_txt:
\(f(x)=x^{3} -6x^{2} +ax+b\)

\[ \Rightarrow f'(x)=3x^{2} -12x+a\]

\[ \Rightarrow f'(c)=0 \Rightarrow f'\left(2+\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } \right)=0\]

\[ \Rightarrow 3\left(2+\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } \right)^{2} -12\left(2+\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } \right)+a=0\]

\[ \Rightarrow 3\left(4+\cfrac{1}{3} +\cfrac{4}{\sqrt{3} } \right)-12\left(2+\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{3} } \right)+a=0\]

\[12+1+4\sqrt{3} -24-4\sqrt{3} +a=0 \Rightarrow a=11.\]

quest_title: The equation of the hyperbola whose foci are (6, 4) and (–4, 4) and eccentricity 2 is given by :
explanation_txt:
The focii share same ordinate, 4. So, ordinate of center is 4. For abscissa of center, midpoint of abscissae of focii is \( (6 - 4)/2 = 1 \). So, vertex is \( (1,4) \). Also, the transverse axis is horizontal. ( \( y=4 \) ).

Hence the equation of hyperbola is \( \cfrac{(x-1)^2}{a^2} - \cfrac{(y-4)^2}{b^2} = 1 \)

Given, \( e = \sqrt{1 + {{b^2} \over {a^2}}} = 2 \)

Also, the abscissae of focus iare \(1 \pm ae = 1 \pm 2a = -4,6\)

This gives \( a = 5/2 \)

From eccentricity's expression, \( b = 5 \sqrt{3} /2 \)

Putting back 'a' and 'b', we get the equation as:

\(12x^2 - 4y^2 - 24x + 32y - 127 = 0 \)

quest_title: If the roots of the equation \(ax^{2} +x+b=0\) be real, then the roots of the equation \(x^{2} -4\sqrt{ab} x+1=0\) will be
explanation_txt:
\(ax^{2} +x+b=0\) has real roots

\(\Rightarrow \)\(1^{2} -4ab\ge 0\, \, \, \Rightarrow -4ab\ge -1\)or \(4ab\le 1\) .....(i)

Now second equation is \(x^{2} -4\sqrt{ab} x+1=0\)

Therefore \(D=16ab-4 = 4 (4ab - 1) \)

from (i) \(D\le 0\)

Hence roots are imaginary.

explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)\( \cfrac{x}{D} = \cfrac{\lambda }{d} \)\(\therefore \) x = \( \cfrac{D\lambda }{d} \)

\(\quad\)Here 2x = d so

\(\quad\)d = \( \cfrac{2D\lambda }{d} \)

\(\quad\)D = \( \cfrac{d^{2}}{2\lambda } \)

quest_title: Let \(\alpha ,\, \, \beta ,\, \, \gamma \) be distinct real numbers. The points with position vectors \(\alpha i+\beta j+\gamma k,\, \, \beta i+\gamma j+\alpha k,\, \, \gamma i+\alpha j+\beta k\)
explanation_txt:
Let \(P,\, Q\) and \(R\) be points having position vectors \(\alpha \, i+\beta \, j+\gamma \, k,\) \(\beta \, i+\gamma \, j+\alpha \, k\) and \(\gamma \, i+\alpha j+\beta k\) respectively.

Then,\(|\overrightarrow{PQ} |\, =\, |\overrightarrow{QR} |\, =\, |\overrightarrow{RP} |\, =\sqrt{(\alpha -\beta )^{2} +(\beta -\gamma )^{2} +(\gamma -\alpha )^{2} } \)

Hence \(\Delta PQR\) is an equilateral triangle.

quest_title: Which of the following has bond angle nearest to \(90^{0}\)?
explanation_txt:
NH3 - 103o (due to presence of lone pair)

H2S - 92.1o (due to presence of lone pair)

H2O - 105o (due to presence of lone pair, higer electonegativity of oxygen than of sulphur)

CH4 - 109.5o (regular tetrahedral)

In H2O, oxygen is more electronegative, electrons of two O-H bonds are more attracted towards oxygen atom. Consequently more bond pair- bond pair repulsion take place,so bond angle increases. On the other hand in H2S, because of less electronegative character of S,less repulsion is present so angle get decrease.
question_plain_title: Which of the following has bond angle nearest to ?
explanation_plain_text:
NH3 - 103o (due to presence of lone pair)

H2S - 92.1o (due to presence of lone pair)

H2O - 105o (due to presence of lone pair, higer electonegativity of oxygen than of sulphur)

CH4 - 109.5o (regular tetrahedral)

In H2O, oxygen is more electronegative, electrons of two O-H bonds are more attracted towards oxygen atom. Consequently more bond pair- bond pair repulsion take place,so bond angle increases. On the other hand in H2S, because of less electronegative character of S,less repulsion is present so angle get decrease.
